results.title: Kombi Karma
results.brief_description: Kombi Karma examines a cultural icon through the eyes of a diverse group of VW Kombi van lovers. Rachael travels the Victorian countryside in her Kombi and describes her camping trips as ‘more comfortable than being at home’. David, a Kombi enthusiast for over 30 years, is fascinated by the van’s early beginnings as an economical utilities vehicle in occupied Germany during World War II. Some tell of their love of the Kombi’s idiosyncratic design, ‘I love the box shape because it’s such a practical thing to put things in’. Andrew lovingly restores Kombis and believes ‘once you’re bitten by it, it never really goes away, once you own one you really wouldn’t want to own any other sort of car’. And Jan has learned to love Kombis again after her former partner smashed her newly restored Kombi to pieces with a wood splitter. But perhaps Ben sums it up best when he explains that being a Kombi devotee means that ‘you are someone who enjoys the journey as much as the destination’.

results.title: An Australian Summer
results.brief_description: A gentle comedy exploring, on a humorous and compassionate level, the shifting relationships within an Australian family over two decades, 1960-1980. The complexities of a family relationship where love as a binding force is tested by disappointment, are evocatively portrayed with a deft mixture of humour and poignancy.

The complexities of a family relationship where love as a binding force is tested by disappointment, are evocatively portrayed with a deft mixture of humour and poignancy.

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Chris Pine disassociating
results.description: Where to start with the premiere of Don’t Worry Darling? The feud between director and star? The leaked texts? Harry Styles seemingly spitting on Chris Pine? By then, Pine had already checked out after enduring co-star Styles praising the cinematic quality of ‘the movie’. All viral moments, but Pine’s dead stare recalls the Sad Affleck meme and can be reused to have his mental retreat express our own, which we may need since Styles’ bumbling also seemed to represent an existential threat to cinema in the streaming age of IP-driven blockbusters, which many hoped ‘the movie’ would defy.
description_for_label: Where to start with the premiere of Don’t Worry Darling. The feud between director and star? The leaked texts? Harry Styles seemingly spitting on Chris Pine? By then, Pine had already checked out after enduring co-star Styles praising the cinematic quality of ‘the movie’. All viral moments, but Pine’s dead stare recalls the Sad Affleck meme and can be reused to have his mental retreat express our own, which we may need since Styles’ bumbling also somehow came off like an existential threat to cinema. Ironic, since many expected ‘the movie’ to be a hit that defied streaming and IP-driven blockbusters.

results.title: Whereas the people
results.brief_description: Traces the development of the Australian Constitution and investigates its relevance for today as well as examining the politics behind its drafting. The continuous “battle” between State and Federal powers is illustrated by the Franklin Dam case and the process of Constitutional change through referendum is explained.

results.title: Big painter
results.brief_description: A chronological study of the production of a mural by John Firth-Smith begun in 1978 and completed in 1981. The huge painting measures 6m x 48m and hangs in the headquarters of the ANZ Bank, Melbourne.
